newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks dodge Wall Street hit, close higher.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks dodge Wall Street hit, close higher.

text.p: Late buying on electronics pushed Taiwan share prices to a sharply higher close on Tuesday as the market dodged the reverberations from Wall Street's big downturn that rattled other major Asian exchanges.

The benchmark index jumped to a higher open after giant Formosa Plastics made peace with Taiwan's government with a Monday pledge to drop a big China power plant investment if Taipei -- as is virtually certain -- denies a permit.
The index rose through the day to close at its intraday high of 8,163.41 for a gain of 159.21 points or 1.99 percent.
Turnover was a brisk T$128.2 billion.
Formosa said on Saturday it already was building the US$3 billion China project in defiance of Taiwan policy, sparking worries to send Taiwan stocks down 1.42 percent on Monday.
"Since Formosa has reached agreement with the economics ministry to back off from its China project, investor worries have eased," said HSBC James Capel analyst Alex Chen.
Late buying focused on electronics, which rose 3.71 percent on a sound outlook entering the second quarter.
Semiconductor packaging firm A.S.E. rose the daily seven percent limit to T$107 and motherboard maker Asustek was limit up to T$666.
Brokers nonetheless cautioned that overconcentration on the dazzling electronics sector was skewing the wider market.
"Electronics, despite their solid sales and profit performance, simply have been overheated," said Jardine Fleming Securities fund manager George Hou.
Car shares rose 4.64 percent as Yulon Motor and China Motor reported good recent sales. Yulon was limit up to T$57.5 and China Motor surged T$3.5 to T$68.
Constructions rose 2.87 percent on reports of good March sales in the beleaguered property market and hopes for a better April, with Pacific Construction up T$1.6 to T$31.4.
